title: Amstel Gold Race 2023: Route, TV guide, start list and all you need to know
content:
Cyclist
Amstel Gold Race 2023: Route, TV guide, start list and all you need to know

The cobbled Classics are done, the Ardennes are to come, and the riders are parched: it’s Amstel Gold Race for both men and women on Sunday 16th April. Named because of its sponsorship by beer company Amstel, its winners are rewarded a glass (sometimes massive, sometimes small) of Amstel to celebrate.

Taking riders through the Limburg region, with riders heading out from Maastricht and circling to the nearby Valkenburg, Amstel Gold seeks out the Netherlands’ biggest climbs to get the riders in the mood for the hilly Belgian races to come in La Flèche Wallonne and Liège-Bastogne-Liège – and even briefly passing through Belgium mid-race – with the headline hill being the Cauberg.

Defending champions are Ineos Grenadiers’ Michał Kwiatkowski and FDJ-Suez’s Marta Cavalli but they’ll face stiff competition from both the peloton’s best climbers and Classics riders, though expect a few of those at the pointy end of Paris-Roubaix to give it a miss. Wout van Aert has already said he won’t be riding the rest of the spring Classics but Tadej Pogačar and Annemiek van Vleuten are expected to be on the start line.

Related Posts

La Flèche Wallonne: Routes, how to watch, teams and everything you need to know

Grubers’ Paris-Roubaix gallery: Finding heaven in Hell

Cycling spring Classics 2023: Race dates, Monuments, cobbles and live TV guide

Amstel Gold Race: Key information

  • Date: Sunday 16th April
  • Start: Maastricht, Netherlands
  • Finish: Valkenburg, Netherlands
  • Distance: 253.6km (men’s); 155.8km (women’s)
  • Live TV coverage: Eurosport, GCN+, Discovery+
  • Previous winners: Michał Kwiatkowski (Ineos Grenadiers); Marta Cavalli (FDJ-Suez)
  • Most wins: Jan Raas (five); Debby Mansveld, Leontien Zijlaard-van Moorsel, Nicole Cooke, Anna van der Breggen, Chantal van den Broek-Blaak, Kasia Niewiadoma, Marianne Vos, Marta Cavalli (one)

Amstel Gold Race 2023 routes and profiles

Women’s parcours

The women’s race has grown for 2023, with total distance up to 155.8km up from last year’s 128.5km and with that comes an extra three climbs through the additional of an extra lap of the 18km loop that includes the Geulhemmerberg, Bemelerberg and Cauberg, which will be taken on four times.

That brings the total climbing to 1,698m.

Men’s parcours

The only changes for the men’s route this year is early on in the race as riders head out towards Sittard before heading towards Valkenburg. One ascent of the Cauberg has also been taken out, but the finale is unchanged with the line coming 1.8km from the final climb of the Cauberg.

That means it’s 253.6km in total with 3,266m of climbing.

Amstel Gold Race 2023: How to watch on TV and streaming

In the UK, Europe and select international territories, the races will be broadcast and live-streamed on Eurosport, GCN+ and Discovery+, with the full race available to watch back afterwards on GCN+ and highlights on YouTube via GCN Racing and Eurosport. GCN provides a full list of which races are available to stream in each country across the world.

UK pricing for a GCN+ subscription is £6.99 a month or £39.99 per year. The online platform is accessible on desktop and phone, offering uninterrupted live coverage and longer broadcasts than the television. GCN+ is ad-free, gives commentary choices and provides cycling-based documentaries to watch.

The Entertainment & Sports pass Discovery+ subscription costs £6.99 a month or £59.99 a year, and you’ll get the same coverage plus access to the platform’s other content including such highlights as Wheeler Dealers and Spooked Scotland.

In the USA and Canada, you can catch the action on Flobikes; coverage in New Zealand will be on Sky; and to watch in Australia both men’s and women’s races will be on SBS.

Live TV and streaming times

All times BST and subject to change by broadcasters.

Women’s

Eurosport 1: 12:00-13:50
GCN+: 12:00-13:30

Men’s

Eurosport 1: 13:50-16:15
GCN+ and Discovery+: 13:30-16:00
